questions.question: Antepartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from the genital tract after
What is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH).Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situatedplacenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type.Causes of APH:•Placental causes:•Abruptio placenta (most common)• Placenta previa (2nd most common)• Circumvallate placenta⚫ Circummarginate placenta•Fetal causes:• Vasa previa•Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions):• Local trauma• Varicose veins• Cervical polyp• Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question: Transvaginal ultrasound findings in a multiparous woman revealed a low lying placenta.What does this mean?

options.A: Placental edge within 2 cm from the internal os
options.B: Placental edge within 3 cm from the internal os
options.C: Placental edge within 4 cm from the internal os

questions.explanation: In low lying placenta, the edge of the placenta lies within 2 cm from the internal os but does notcover the internal os.Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted over the lower uterine segment(partially or completely).ACOG classification of placenta previa:••• True placenta previa - placenta covers the internal os partially or completely•Low lying placenta - placenta does not cover the internal os but the edge is within 2 cm of theinternal os380

questions.question: Which of the following types are included in the major degrees of placenta previa?
questions.explanation: Major degree of placenta previa includes posterior marginal, partial and complete central.Clinical classification of placenta previa:• Mild degree• Type I or lateral or low lying.• Type II anterior or anterior marginal•Major degree• Type II posterior or posterior marginal or dangerous placenta previaType III or partial central.• Type IV or completeOlder (Browne's) classification of placenta previa:TypePositionTypeLateralITypeMarginalIITypeIncomplete or partial centralIIITypeComplete or centralIV

questions.question: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presented at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints ofrecurrent painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, fundal height corresponded togestational age and fetal heart rate was 140 bpm. Which of the following is not a risk factorfor this condition?
questions.explanation: DefinitionThe placenta dips into the lower segment but does not reach up to the osThe placental edge reaches the osThe placenta partially coversthe internal osThe placenta completely covers the internal osTypes of Placenta PreviaType ILow implantationLoType IIIRROType IIMarginalPartial IncompleteMARROWType IVCentral / Complete381The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa. Pre-eclampsia is a risk factor forabruptio placenta, not placenta previa.Painless bleeding PV, fundal height proportional to gestational age and presence of FHS are thedifferentiating features of placenta previa from abruptio placenta.Risk factors for placenta previa are:• Demographic factors• Maternal age >35 years•MultiparityCigarette smoking• Clinical factors••• Prior caesarean sectionPast history of placenta previa• Artificial reproductive technology•Multifetal pregnancy•Succenturiate lobe.

questions.question: Per speculum examination findings in a pregnant woman with vaginal bleeding showedplacenta protruding through the cervical os. What is the type of placenta previa in this case?
questions.explanation: Placenta protruding through the internal os on per speculum examination indicates completeplacenta previa or type IV placenta previa.Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa:Cervical digital examination must only be done in suspected cases of placenta previa in anoperation theater with provisions for cesarean section kept ready.TypePositionTypeLateralITypeMarginalIITypeIncomplete or partial centralIIITypeComplete or centralIVDefinitionThe placenta dips into the lower segment but does not reach up to the osThe placental edge reaches the osThe placenta partially coversthe internal osThe placenta completely covers the internal os382Types of Placenta PreviaType ILow implantationLORROType IIMarginalType IIIPartial IncompleteType IVCentral CompleteOMARROW

questions.question: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation presented with placenta previa. Which of the following isfalse about this condition?

options.A: Painful recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen
options.B: The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age

questions.explanation: Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa.Clinical features of placenta previa:• Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes ahistory of warning haemorrhage is present•Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation• Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into thepelvis• Fetal heart sound present-• Stallworthy sign - seen in low lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heartrate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure isrelieved, is called Stallworthy sign.

questions.question: 373Abdominal examination during a routine antenatal checkup gave a positive Stallworthy sign.What could be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa.The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptlywhen the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetalhead compression.383

questions.question: A G2P1 woman presents to the casualty at 30 weeks with a history of self-limiting painlessbleeding PV 3 hours ago. On examination, BP - 110/70 mmHg and PR - 80 bpm. What is thenext best step in management?

options.A: Transvaginal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis
options.B: Start injection corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of antepartum haemorrhage (APH) due to placenta previa(painless bleeding PV). The next step in the management is to confirm the diagnosis withtransvaginal ultrasound (TVS) as the patient is stable.Transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) is used to detect the cause of APH.If the placenta is in the lower uterine segment on TAS, confirmation of placenta previa is done byTVS. TVS provides a clearer image of the relationship between the edge of the placenta and theinternal cervical os than TAS.Approach to placenta previa after confirmation with TVS:• Minor placenta previa - repeat USG at 36 weeks.•Major placenta previa or accreta - USG at 32 weeks followed by elective caesarean deliveryBleeding present - individual managementOn TAS, if the placenta is in the upper uterine segment with evidence of retroplacental blood clot,abruptio placenta is suspected.Per vaginal examination in placenta previa must not be done as it may further separate theplacenta and cause excessive bleeding. However, transvaginal ultrasound is safe as long as theprobe is 2-3 cm away from the cervix.

questions.question: A G2P1L1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation was rushed to the casualty with complaints ofpainless vaginal bleeding. She had woken up to find herself in a pool of blood. Onexamination, her vitals were unstable. Active bleeding per vaginum was present. Which of thefollowing complications would not be anticipated in her?
questions.explanation: Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not acomplication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole.Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity,and often occurs during sleep.Complications of placenta previa:Maternal complications:Fetal complications:• Low birth weight•Asphyxia• Intrauterine death• Birth injuries•Congenital malformations.PeriodComplicationAntepart Antepartum haemorrhageMaumlpresentationPreterm labour384PeriodIntrapartumPostpartComplicationEarly rupture of membranesSlow dilatation of cervixPostpartum haemorrhageumPuerperiumSepsisSubinvolution

questions.question: Transvaginal ultrasound in a multiparous woman at 32 weeks confirmed placenta previa. Hervitals are stable and there is no active bleeding PV. What is the next step in management?

options.C: Manage as per McAfee and Johnson method
options.D: Manage as per Sher and Page grading

questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the next best step of management is conservative management till37 weeks i.e., McAfee and Johnson's regimen.The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity withoutcompromising maternal health.Prerequisites:• Blood for transfusion• Facilities for cesarean sectionSelection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa:• Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%)•⚫ Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks•No active vaginal bleeding• Fetus reactive on cardiotocography and no congenital anomalies on USGConduct of expectant treatment:• Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity• Bed rest or pelvic rest• Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV• Fetal surveillance with USG•Tocolytics if contractions are present• Anti-D to all Rh-negative unsensitized womenOption A: Immediate caesarean section after resuscitation is done if the patient is unstable.Option B: Vaginal delivery is considered when the edge of the placenta is >2 cm away from theinternal os.Option D: Sher and Page grading is for abruptio placenta.

questions.question: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.explanation: 385The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which wasadvocated by McAfee and Johnson.The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity withoutcompromising maternal health.Prerequisites:• Availability of blood for transfusion• Facilities for cesarean section availableSelection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa:••Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%)⚫ Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks•No active vaginal bleeding• Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTGConduct of expectant treatment:•Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity• Bed rest or pelvic rest• Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv• Fetal surveillance with USG•Tocolytics if contractions are present• Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics?
questions.explanation: Placental abruption is the most common cause of severe consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics.Consumptive coagulopathy, also known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), is apathologic disruption of hemostasis. It is characterized by systemic activation of bloodcoagulation, which results in thrombosis and fibrin deposition in the small blood vesselsthroughout the body.Other causes of DIC in pregnancy:• Amniotic fluid embolism•Sepsis• Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome• Acute fatty liver of pregnancy• Postpartum haemorrhage.386

questions.question: Which of the following does not increase the risk of placental abruption?
questions.explanation: Post term pregnancy does not increase the risk of abruptio placenta.Risk factors for placental abruption:• Prior abruption• Increased age and parity• Pre-eclampsia and chronic hypertension•Chorioamnionitis• Preterm ruptured membranes• Multifetal gestation••Cocaine useCigarette smoking• Uterine leiomyomas• Single umbilical artery.

questions.question: Which of the following clinical features can be seen in a patient presenting with accidentalhaemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Abruptio placenta is also known as accidental haemorrhage or premature separation of placenta.Tender uterus is seen in abruptio placenta.Abruptio placenta is defined as premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It is of thefollowing types:• Concealed• Revealed• MixedClinical features of abruptio placenta:In mixed type, features of concealed variety will be predominant.FeaturesGeneral conditionSymptomsUterine heightFHSRevealedProportionate to visible blood lossAbdominal discomfort or pain followed by bleedingProportionate to the period of gestationUsually presentConcealedShock may be pronounced which may be out of proportion to visible bleeding.Abdominal acute intense painNo or minimal bleedingMaybe disproportionately enlargedUsually absent387

questions.question: A multiparous woman at 34 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vaginum and wasdiagnosed to have grade 2 abruptio placenta. Which of the following features may be seen inher?
questions.explanation: Grade 2 abruptio placenta is characterized by fetal distress.Sher and Page clinical classification of placental abruption:Grade o of abruptio placenta is seen in an asymptomatic patient, where a retroplacental clot isobserved only after delivery of placenta.FeatureGrade 1Grade 2Vaginal bleedingSlightMild to moderateUterine tendernessMaternal BP and pulse rateFetal conditionMinimalPresentUnaffectedBP maintainedPulse rate increasedFHS goodFetal distressMaternal fibrinogenUnaffect DecreasededGrade 3Moderate to severe or concealed typeMarkedHypovolemic shockAnuriaFetal deathCoagulation defect

questions.question: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lowerabdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was notedand she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below. Which ofthe following is true regarding this condition?

options.A: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
options.B: It is an indication for hysterectomy
options.C: It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.explanation: The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severeforms of concealed abruptio placenta.There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, theuterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broadligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.question: Colour doppler studies in a patient with velamentous cord insertion revealed fetal vesselswhich were overlying the cervical os. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?

options.B: Bleeding is triggered by membrane rupture
options.C: Bleeding is managed by category I caesarian section

questions.explanation: The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa,but fetal mortality is seen.Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervicalos. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination.388Placenta-Vasa previaWOMARROW-Umbilicalcord-Fetal bloodvessels-Internal osInvestigations of vasa previa:• Colour flow Doppler (TVS)••Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect nucleated red blood cells.-• Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobinManagement of vasa previa:• No bleeding• 28-32 weeks antenatal corticosteroids-• 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance• ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section• Bleeding present• Category I emergency caesarean section is done (immediate threat to the life of mother or fetus.and decision delivery interval <30 mins)

questions.question: Sample from a patient with bleeding PV at 30 weeks showed a positive Apt test. What is themost probable cause?
questions.explanation: Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). It is positive in vasaprevia and Rh incompatibility.Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. Itis done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 10% NaOH.Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency caesarean section.Hence, Apt test is not practically done in all cases.Other options: Bleeding due to cervical polyp, placenta previa, and abruptio placenta is ofmaternal origin. So, Apt test will be negative in these cases.389

questions.question: Which of the following investigations can be used in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa ina patient with no history of bleeding PV?
questions.explanation: The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by colour doppler.Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervicalos. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination.Investigations of vasa previa:• Colour flow Doppler (TVS)•Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect nucleated red blood cells-• Apt test to detect fetal haemoglobin-Management of vasa previa:• No bleeding••28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids• 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance≥37 weeks elective caesarean section-• Bleeding present•Emergency caesarean section done by category IOptions A and B: Colour Doppler is superior to MRI and TAS in the antenatal diagnosis of vasaprevia.Option D: Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect fetal RBCs can be used in intrapartumdiagnosis of vasa previa (as there might be bleeding).

questions.question: A multiparous woman at term presents to the labour room with bleeding per vaginum andruptured membranes. NST shows fetal distress and sinusoidal heart rate pattern. How willyou manage this patient?

options.A: Rapid induction and delivery by vacuum377
options.B: Rapid induction and delivery by forceps
options.D: Adopt Vagos method and rapid vaginal delivery

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vasa previa since bleeding is associated with fetaldistress and sinusoidal pattern in NST. Actively bleeding vasa previa in a term gestation ismanaged by immediate LSCS.Sinusoidal pattern in CTG is a regular, smooth, undulating signal resembling a sine wave. It canbe seen in conditions associated with severe fetal anemia like:• Anti-D allo-immunisation• Fetal-maternal haemorrhage••Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome•• Ruptured vasa previa• Acute fetal hypoxia• Infection390• Cardiac malformations• Hydrocephalus• GastroschisisSinusoidal pattern on CTG:18016014012010080Sinusoidal pattern60MA1801601401201008060Fetal heart rate18016014012010080OW60100100808010080606060404040202020000Uterine contractionsOMARROWManagement of vasa previa:• No bleeding• 28-32 weeks antenatal corticosteroids-• 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance• ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section• Bleeding present.• Emergency caesarean sectionNote: Vagos method is used in the management of umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.question: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except
questions.explanation: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism does not include metabolic acidosis.Classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism:•⚫ Hypotension• Hypoxia•⚫ DICConditions predisposing to the development of amniotic fluid embolism:• Rapid labour391• Meconium-stained amniotic fluid• Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins• Older maternal age• Post-term pregnancy⚫ Labour induction or augmentation•• Eclampsia••Cesarean/forceps/vacuum deliveryPlacental abruption/placenta previa• Polyhydramnios.

questions.question: A G2P1L1 woman presented with placental abruption and was delivered by normal vaginaldelivery. The next day, she develops petechiae, cold extremities, and her BP drops to 90/60mmHg. Her blood reports show increased FDP, D-dimer, and decreased platelets. Which ofthe following is not used in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).Epsilon-aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid are not used in the treatment of DIC.Evaluation and management of DIC:⚫ Vigorous restoration and maintenance of circulation to treat hypotension•• Crystalloids and colloids to treat hypotension• Whole blood and packed cells••• Fresh frozen plasma - contains fibrinogen, antithrombin III, factors V, XI, XIICryoprecipitate - contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, von Willebrand's factor, factor XIII• Platelet replacement if low• Identification of the cause:•Abruptio placenta• PPH•⚫ HELLP syndrome• Amniotic fluid embolism•⚫ Sepsis•• Acute fatty liver• Assess the fetal condition and plan for termination of pregnancy.392
